A fascinating, even if somewhat wrong, thread.

First, the error.

Who pays is not as simple as presented here. The China manufacturer may normally want a 40% gross margin, but the tariffs have just raised the cost of a China-sourced suit by $61. Remember China’s sole value-added in this suit is $10 of labor. If Bangladesh can make this same suit with $30 in labor, then the Chinese mfr has to accept a lower margin. Landed cost is now $275 from Bangladesh vs $302.50 from China (w/Tariffs). So China mfr must price at $220 to be competitive w/25% tariff ($275/1.25) lowering their gross margin to 34.1%.

But they’ve now shifted from a $242 vs $275 advantage to being par with Bangladesh, so volume likely falls, reducing fixed cost absorption.

Likewise, the end price of the suit has still risen as $275 marked up 150% is $687.50 vs $605. As Derek has noted, clothing demand is highly price elastic, meaning quantity demanded will fall sharply with a 13% price increase. So the clothing retailer in the U.S. is going to have lower margins (unless a monopolist). Let’s guess that the retailer takes the same 10% margin hit as manufacturer to prevent demand collapse. Then the markup on $275 is 127% for a retail price of $625 vs $605.

So retail price rises by 3.3% and China profits, especially after calculating share loss to Bangladesh, fall by a giant amount.

Still think the U.S. consumer pays?

I appreciate the discussion on this board. For the most part, it is a genuine attempt to understand by genuinely interested investors.

I am the Chief Strategist of a firm that provides both active and "passive" (systematic index investing since there are no "passive" products -- it's a lie that's been sold) products. My research on passive is widely available, and I share it generously. I am always willing to defend my position with data and analysis. I do not gain financially if my concerns are realized. In fact, like most of you, I will be measurably worse off if I'm right.

When someone like Ben Felix is willing to genuinely review the arguments, they inevitably reach the same conclusion.

In contrast, passive proponents like Rick Ferri refuse to even have a discussion because it would harm their business to be shown lacking in substance.

For those who have not followed my recommendations, this is what I advise:

1. Larger cash holdings are required to provide internal liquidity for larger funds. It is a disaster waiting to happen when firms rely on market liquidity at the scale of Vanguard. Read the prospectuses. Vanguard is utilizing more and more derivatives to facilitate its growth.

2. There should not be PREFERENTIAL treatment of quantitative strategies – no “index returns” or backtest exceptions for index products. Backtests presume that the strategy does not affect the market it trades. This was why I was able to predict the implosion of XIV and I'm assuring you the situation for the broader stockmarket is much, much worse.

3. Enforce diversification rules! Funds like Vanguard's S&P500 Growth fund are in violation of the 1940 Act for diversified funds and are only able to marketed to retail because Vanguard has lobbied for exceptions.

3. The industry has become monopolistic due to failure to enforce existing regulations. “Bundling” in retirement plans, QDIAs (qualified default investment alternatives), and fees charged to fund managers by platforms like Fidelity raise the cost to consumers and reduce your choices. I want to preserve the benefits of passive investing for smaller investors who should not be expected to "Do your own work" while recognizing that there is harm created when it is pushed to current scale.

4. Open market buyback operations and accelerated share repurchases were banned pre-1982 to prevent stock market manipulation. In a market made increasingly inelastic by passive investing strategies, they simply enrich the executives at the largest firms. "Britain, France, and Ukraine have agreed to collaboratively develop a ceasefire plan to present to the United States"

I'm not glorifying, just emphasizing. Europe had no choice. It may be rude to point that out, and it certainly leads to hurt feelings and possible resentment against America... but those already existed.

This is the best outcome of a bad situation and now we can move forward with cheap, DIVERSIFIED, natgas for Europe, a surge in petrochemical supplies as Germany comes back online, etc AND a Europe that recognizes the need to rebuild defensive capabilities while remaining under a broad, but distant umbrella of American military force.

Meanwhile, China and India no longer get half price energy/commodities as Russia returns to selling in the full price market. Major win for the West, regardless of the other implications. Will Putin break the ceasefire? Why? He was just promoted from junior partner with China to senior partner European branch. Not managing partner, but a strong voice at the table and a requirement to take him seriously.

We'll have to see the terms, but imho this is a hugely positive development in both strategic and economic terms. We can worry about the implications of perceived appeasement going forward (remember that we fight the 'last war' suggesting this fear may be as misplaced today as it was correct in 1938), but I honestly believe we've been appeasing the wrong side -- the war-making elites who view "War as just" rather than policymaking by other means.

It is a misconception that the U.S. won WW1 and WW2 because of our existing manufacturing capability. Ship building in the U.S. was high cost and the U.S. represented less than 5% of global shipbuilding in 1939.

The VAST majority of U.S. ship building capacity is dedicated to repair and service of existing ships. That is a high cost, labor intensive effort.  New ship building? Well don’t take my word for it…

“Relatively speaking, new construction is a repetitive process to a large degree. Overhaul and conversion work is seldom if ever repetitive. Even among ships of the same class receiving identical alterations, the work requirements will vary, sometimes to a remarkable extent.” https://t.co/XE3aJBNnXN

Note the date (1964). Debates about US ship building capacity have existed for well over 150 years as the article highlights. I am among the first to highlight risks of reliance on China, but the much bigger risk here is an absurd allocation of labor and capital to build a maritime force we simply don’t need YET.
